messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Re: Samurai Inquiry + YAKUZA
messages.msgSnippet: All, whilst this is not really what Jason is looking for, it reminded me of one of my favorite flicks, and I am going to sit down to it right now, Sydney
messages.messageBody:
All, whilst this is not really what Jason is looking for, it reminded me
of one of my favorite flicks, and I am going to sit down to it right
now, Sydney Polak's "the Yakuza" with Robert Mitchum and Takakura Ken.
It may or may not be accurate, but I think it is a great flick.

Rich Turner

messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Re: Samurai Inquiry + YAKUZA
messages.msgSnippet: G day Jason, Welcome.  I know how much my life and sword interests broadened when I found the first sword lists back in 1995.  This Samurai History list came
messages.messageBody:
G'day Jason,
Welcome. I know how much my life and sword interests broadened when I found
the first sword lists back in 1995. This Samurai History list came much
later. But to your question re the Yakuza and their history. I have only
one book and it seems to cover them from Go to Whoa (well, still going!).
They began to attract the attention of officials around 1612... Well, go
find a copy of the (paperback, 414 pages):

YAKUZA
The explosive account of Japan's criminal underworld
Alex Dubro and David E Kaplan
Futura (1986)
ISBN 0 7088 3573 2

Best regards,
Barry Thomas (Melbourne, Australia)

----- Original Message -----
From: Jason <jtanjian@...>
To: <samuraihistory@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Friday, October 15, 2004 10:55 AM
Subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Re: Samurai Inquiry

Hello Brothers;
Firstly i am new to the forum and as i have been reading along the past
few days i have seen truly, in my humble opinion...the best gathering of
shared knowledge, truth, and comraderie since my days as a U.S. Marine.
Stating that everyone here has a passion for the subject and era(s) would be
a gross understatement. I have been reading & researching Japanese history
for the better part of my life and i am finally within a group where i feel
i can converse openly, freely & most of all...continue to learn. Please
pardon me for being overly ecstatic, but this forum is just truly what i
have been looking for in a nutshell. I have recently returned from Okinawa,
Japan...but luckily for me i am sure none of you will hold that against me
(i hope that was funny to some, give me a little face...please) but have
been over mainland Japan as well and there are not many places in Japan or
Asia period that i have not traveled. On my own or through the U.S.
Military. So i offer my modest thanks and praise for being able to exist
within the forum...
Secondly; i agree with the statements of Mr. Wayland...to request for
information one must truly want to seek the truth. As i am sure we all know,
one of the staples of Bushido was that it was commonplace to seek
constructive criticism from your peers...for as Tsunetomo said: "If you
judge and manage every affair while depending only on your small learning
and wisdom...etc." The point is that you cannot ask a question with the
intention of getting only the answer you desire.
Thirdly; i wanted to acquire some books or writings if possible
explaining the history of the Yakuza as a sort of "police force" in their
origination, i am not sure if this is correct, but i am really looking for a
sort of timeline from their beginning and how they progressed and changed.
Any assistance in this manner would be extremely grateful. Continued
Blessings!





--- On Wed 10/13, Nate Ledbetter < ltdomer98@... > wrote:
From: Nate Ledbetter [mailto: ltdomer98@...]
To: samuraihistory@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Oct 2004 19:44:42 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Re: Samurai Inquiry

<html><body>


<tt>
My use of the phrase "bad romance novel" in no way,<BR>
shape, or form, justified an attack on my person using<BR>
foul language. That is not the act of someone who<BR>
wants answers. The impression is that this person read<BR>
something somewhere, potentially fictional, and<BR>
believes it to be real. Fine--no problem. To me, it<BR>
doesn't sound real. It certainly doesn't sound like<BR>
anything I'm familiar with, at least with no further<BR>
information to draw from. However, I'm fully willing<BR>
to grant it may be a story based on some real events,<BR>
and would be happy to help find what those events<BR>
were, if I could. I cannot, especially when told "I<BR>
know more about this, but won't tell you." Please.<BR>
<BR>
It is not the responsibility of anyone on this board<BR>
to soothe egoes or confirm erroneous beliefs. You have<BR>
the right to incorrectly believe geisha existed in<BR>
1600--you do not have the right to call people who<BR>
tell you that you are incorrect and present facts<BR>
dirty names. <BR>
<BR>
My reply may have been sardonic, but was not<BR>
offensive. I didn't call anyone any names. As a<BR>
subordinate list moderator, I was well within my<BR>
rights granted by Kitsuno to simply delete the email<BR>
and ban the person from posting. I did not, as it was<BR>
an attack directly on me--I chose not to act so I<BR>
could not be accused of acting out of malice. Kitsuno<BR>
can decide to ban or not ban, delete or not delete. <BR>
<BR>
If you want information, this is a great place to be.<BR>
If you want affirmation, go see a therapist. <BR>
<BR>
<BR>
--- Kitsuno <samurai-listowner@...><BR>
wrote:<BR>
<BR>
> <BR>
> It really is not an issue of scholarship. First he<BR>
> asks a vague <BR>
> question, which is fine. but he also later mentions<BR>
> that he has more <BR>
> information that he then refuses to release, which<BR>
> tells me he isnt <BR>
> very interested in getting information. The<BR>
> response that offended <BR>
> him seemed pretty benign to me, but that is just my<BR>
> humble opinion. <BR>
> Regardless, it makes sense to me that if you ask a<BR>
> question, you try <BR>
> to include as much information as possible, which he<BR>
> apparently <BR>
> didnt do if he is now bragging about having other<BR>
> information. <BR>
> Anyway, these groups are pretty easy, but not always<BR>
> a one way <BR>
> street. Just because you ask for someone to do your<BR>
> homework for you <BR>
> doesnt mean they will do it willingly. People tend<BR>
> to want a reason <BR>
> to do you work for you. That was part of what I was<BR>
> trying to say.<BR>
> <BR>
> <BR>
> --- In samuraihistory@yahoogroups.com, "Barry<BR>
> Thomas" <warlord@i...> <BR>
> wrote:<BR>
> > <BR>
> > Dear Brothers,<BR>
> > <BR>
> > > Regardless of your emotional state, this:<BR>
> > >> ...<BR>
> > > is brutally vague in the extreme. If you cant<BR>
> give a single<BR>
> > > detail more on this, or even where you found it,<BR>
> I can<BR>
> > > guarantee that no one will be able to help<BR>
> you...<BR>
> > <BR>
> > Well, granted the original presentation was far<BR>
> from scholarly, <BR>
> but surely<BR>
> > I'm not the only one to (a) find it intriguing and<BR>
> (b) find a <BR>
> little bell<BR>
> > ringing in my head, not from the Sengoku Jidai but<BR>
> from mid-Edo. <BR>
> Granted<BR>
> > the riposte from our original questioner was a far<BR>
> from measured <BR>
> response,<BR>
> > but the replies from Dear List Owner and others<BR>
> whose name/s <BR>
> escape me<BR>
> > hardly encourages anyone to ask any question at<BR>
> all, no matter how <BR>
> seemingly<BR>
> > not PC for the eminent scholars on this list. <BR>
> Reminds of the <BR>
> lampoons I<BR>
> > have got... So, why do I persist with this list? <BR>
> Because I love <BR>
> the<BR>
> > subject matter and see it as an important adjunct<BR>
> to my sword <BR>
> studies and<BR>
> > collecting, and because the awesome knowledge of<BR>
> practitioners in <BR>
> the field<BR>
> > just takes my breath away.<BR>
> > <BR>
> > Can't we be a little less uptight on this list??<BR>
> > <BR>
> > Barry Thomas<BR>
> > (Melbourne, Australia - just over the road from<BR>
> Jim Breen's campus)<BR>
> <BR>
> <BR>
> <BR>
> <BR>
<BR>
<BR>
<BR>
<BR>
